The transition is smooth and continuous, and all visual cues accurately reflect the increase in disorder (entropy) as expected from the teaching point. Any deviation from perfect realism is negligible or imperceptible.

teaching_point: Entropy increases when energy becomes more spread out and less available to do useful work.
visual_explanation: Show hot gas particles in one half of a box. After removing a partition, the gas spreads evenly throughout, symbolizing energy spreading out and becoming less usable.

video_question.Description1: After the partition is removed, the gas particles clump together in the center, move in synchronized patterns, or spell words in the air. Alternatively, the particles flow uphill against gravity or vanish and reappear randomly throughout the box, violating conservation of energy and particle number.
video_question.Description2: The gas particles briefly spread out but then suddenly all rush back to their original half, or some particles freeze in place mid-air while others accelerate without collisions. The distribution becomes more uneven over time, with particles piling up in corners or forming unnatural, static clusters.
video_question.Description3: The gas does start to spread when the partition is removed, but the motion is jerky or inconsistent—some particles stop moving or inexplicably reverse direction. The overall spread is uneven, with clear gaps or clumps remaining, and thermal motion is not convincingly random. The process looks unnatural but not absurd.
video_question.Description4: The gas particles spread out after the partition is removed, but there are minor flaws—such as a slight delay before motion starts, awkward bouncing off walls, or a few particles taking noticeably longer to disperse. The final distribution is mostly even, but some small asymmetries or unnatural pauses are visible.
video_question.Description5: When the partition is removed, all gas particles begin random motion, quickly and smoothly filling the entire box. The movement is convincingly random, and the final distribution of particles is nearly uniform, accurately illustrating energy spreading out and entropy increasing. Any imperfections are negligible or hard to notice.

teaching_point: Converging lenses (convex) focus parallel rays of light to a single point known as the focal point.
visual_explanation: Show parallel rays of sunlight entering a clear convex lens. Slowly trace each ray bending inward and meeting at a single bright point on the opposite side, labeled 'F'. Use a zoom-in to emphasize the convergence and lens shape.

video_question.Description1: The rays pass through the convex lens completely unchanged, or bend in random, swirling directions, or even split apart into multiple colors without cause. Rays might form a floating shape or word, or the focal point drifts or glows magically far from where it should be. The lens itself might float or change shape unrealistically.
video_question.Description2: The rays enter the convex lens but instead of converging, they diverge further apart or pass straight through without bending. Alternatively, some rays might bend in the wrong direction, or the focal point is shown clearly outside of the axis, or some rays stop abruptly or bounce off the lens surface like a mirror.
video_question.Description3: Most rays bend toward the axis after passing through the lens, but not all meet at the same point—some rays overshoot or undershoot the focal point, or the convergence is noticeably spread out. The convergence is not sharp or the focal point appears slightly fuzzy or off-axis. Lens shape may be slightly inaccurate but recognizably convex.
video_question.Description4: All rays generally converge near the focal point, but one or two rays are slightly misaligned, or the convergence happens just before or after the labeled 'F' point. There may be a delay or slight hesitation in the tracing of the rays, but the overall behavior is almost correct.
video_question.Description5: All parallel rays bend correctly through the convex lens and meet precisely at the bright focal point labeled 'F' on the correct side of the lens. The zoom and lens shape accurately emphasize the concept, and all visual behavior matches real-world optics for a converging lens.

teaching_point: Diverging lenses (concave) spread out parallel rays of light away from a single point.
visual_explanation: Show parallel light rays entering a concave lens. As they pass through, animate each ray bending outward. Extend dotted lines backward behind the lens to intersect at a point labeled 'F'.

video_question.Description1: Light rays enter the concave lens and instead of bending, they loop around in spirals, change colors, or merge together in midair, with dotted lines never intersecting or forming fantastical shapes. Visual effects are magical or surreal, entirely disregarding physical optics.
video_question.Description2: Light rays pass through the concave lens and either continue straight without bending, or all converge to a real point focus on the far side of the lens, as if the lens were converging, not diverging. Dotted lines may not be present, or do not make physical sense relative to the rays’ paths.
video_question.Description3: Most rays bend outward, but some curve inconsistently (e.g., some rays bend too much or too little, or in the wrong direction). Dotted lines might not precisely intersect at a single point, or the rays start bending before reaching the lens. The sequence is off, but generally resembles the idea of divergence.
video_question.Description4: All rays bend outward after passing through the lens, but the bending angles are slightly exaggerated, or there's a momentary lag before they diverge. Dotted lines almost, but not perfectly, meet at a single point, or labels are slightly misplaced. The deviations are minor and don't significantly detract from the teaching point.
video_question.Description5: Parallel light rays enter the concave lens, and each ray bends outward at the lens surfaces according to the rules of refraction. Dotted lines extended backward from the rays intersect precisely at a single focal point labeled 'F', all motions are smooth and consistent with real-world optics. The animation accurately demonstrates divergence by a concave lens.

teaching_point: The image formed by a concave lens is always virtual, upright, and smaller than the object, no matter where the object is placed.
visual_explanation: Place an object (e.g., a candle) in front of a concave lens. Show the principal rays: one parallel (diverges as if from focal point), one toward the center (passes straight). Mark the rays' extensions meeting behind the object to form a small upright virtual image.

video_question.Description1: The video shows rays passing through the concave lens and converging to form a real, inverted image on the other side of the lens, or the lens magnifies the object to a gigantic size. The rays might behave magically—bending in zigzags, looping, or even passing straight through the lens unchanged. The image forms in midair, glows, or appears animated in impossible ways.
video_question.Description2: The video has the rays diverging from the lens but they appear to intersect in front of the lens, forming a real, upright image. Alternatively, the image appears upright but larger than the object. The rays do not follow expected paths (e.g., a parallel ray bends incorrectly, or the central ray is diverted). The image might briefly flip orientation or location in ways that contradict the lens's properties.
video_question.Description3: The video mostly shows rays diverging correctly, but the construction is inconsistent: the extensions of the rays behind the lens don’t quite meet at a single point, or the virtual image is only slightly smaller or nearly the same size as the object. There may be a brief moment where the image appears laterally shifted, blurred, or its orientation is ambiguous. The principal ray paths are mostly, but not entirely, correct.
video_question.Description4: The video shows nearly correct ray behavior and image formation, but with minor flaws—such as a slight misalignment in where the rays' extensions meet, or a minor delay in the image appearing. The size of the image is just a bit off (not quite small enough), or the image flickers briefly. All major aspects (upright, virtual, smaller) are depicted, but there is a small technical inaccuracy or awkwardness in the animation.
video_question.Description5: The video accurately depicts a candle in front of a concave lens, with the principal rays behaving as expected: the parallel ray diverges as if from the focal point, the central ray passes straight through, and their extensions behind the lens meet at a point where a small, upright, virtual image is correctly marked. The timing and sequence are smooth, with no visible errors or deviations from physical reality.

teaching_point: Resonance occurs when a system is driven by an external force at its natural frequency, leading to large amplitude oscillations.
visual_explanation: Show a child sitting on a swing. Initially, the pushes are irregular, and the swing barely moves. Then, demonstrate the child being pushed at regular intervals matching the swing’s natural back-and-forth motion. With each well-timed push, the swing’s amplitude increases noticeably. Clearly highlight that the energy transfer is most efficient when the pushing frequency matches the swing’s natural frequency.

video_question.Description1: The swing begins to levitate, spin, or move in impossible ways regardless of how or when pushes are applied. The child might fly off at random, or the swing reaches infinite amplitude instantly. There are magical effects such as glowing energy waves, or the swing responds to pushes even when no one is pushing, completely disregarding the laws of motion.
video_question.Description2: The swing's motion does not correspond at all to the timing or strength of pushes: for example, the swing slows down or stops entirely when pushed at its natural frequency, or gains maximum height from random, weak, or mistimed pushes. The amplitude might decrease or stay constant no matter how well-timed the pushes are, contradicting resonance. The sequence shows persistent impossible behaviors (e.g., the swing passes through the support structure, or pushes act with a visible delay of many seconds).
video_question.Description3: Several aspects are inconsistent with real resonance: the swing’s amplitude increases with semi-regular or even mistimed pushes, or the amplitude increases far too rapidly (after only one or two pushes), or the swing doesn’t lose any energy between pushes (no damping at all). The child might be shown gaining height even when the timing is noticeably off, or the swing’s period changes for no reason. The physics is off, but the general idea of 'more amplitude with better-timed pushes' is at least somewhat visible.
video_question.Description4: Most of the animation matches expected behavior, but there are small flaws: the swing might respond a bit too quickly or slowly to changes in push timing, or the amplitude increases are slightly exaggerated. There could be a brief moment where a mistimed push has a larger effect than expected, or the swing’s motion looks a little awkward or jerky, but overall the resonance effect is clear and mostly accurate.
video_question.Description5: The swing only gains significant amplitude when pushed at regular intervals matching its natural frequency; irregular pushes have little effect as expected. The amplitude builds up gradually over several well-timed pushes, and the swing’s motion is smooth and physically plausible. Energy transfer is clearly most efficient at resonance, and all details (timing, amplitude growth, damping if included) faithfully reflect the real physics of resonance in a playground swing.

teaching_point: Different systems have different natural frequencies; resonance occurs only when the driving frequency matches the system’s natural frequency.
visual_explanation: Show three identical glass goblets placed side by side, each labeled with a different natural frequency (f₁, f₂, f₃). A nearby speaker emits a sound that gradually sweeps across frequencies. When the sound matches f₂, the middle goblet begins to visibly vibrate, possibly showing cracking or distortion. The other goblets remain unaffected. Use animated wave patterns to visually represent the matching frequencies.

video_question.Description1: All three goblets float, levitate, or shatter spontaneously regardless of the sound frequency. The speaker emits colorful magical bolts, and goblets vibrate or break at random, completely unrelated to the driving sound. Wave patterns morph into fantastical shapes (e.g., animals or symbols) instead of matching the physics of resonance.
video_question.Description2: Goblets start vibrating or breaking even when the driving frequency is far from their labeled natural frequencies, or all goblets vibrate simultaneously regardless of the frequency. The speaker causes visible effects before any plausible frequency match. Wave patterns appear arbitrary or are not synchronized with the goblets' responses.
video_question.Description3: The middle goblet vibrates as expected at f₂, but one or both of the other goblets also show visible motion or mild vibration despite the frequency not matching their natural frequencies. The middle goblet might start vibrating slightly before or after the correct frequency. Wave patterns only partially correspond to the frequency matching.
video_question.Description4: The middle goblet begins to vibrate at f₂ as expected, but there is a slight lag in response or the vibration is visually awkward (e.g., amplitude grows too quickly or not smoothly). Perhaps one of the other goblets shows a tiny, brief motion that quickly dies out. Wave patterns are mostly correct but could have minor synchronization issues.
video_question.Description5: Only the middle goblet vibrates, and only when the speaker's frequency matches f₂. The goblet's motion builds up gradually and naturally, showing possible cracking or distortion. The other goblets remain still throughout. Animated wave patterns precisely align with the moment of resonance, visually reinforcing the teaching point without any distracting or inaccurate effects.
